section.name: Working with Plain Old Java Objects (POJOs)

body.section:
The 'flexibility' afforded by working with Plain Old Java Objects is bought at a price, namely the use of introspection.
The use of a system such as POEM has the disadvantage that, due to Java's lack of multiple inheritance, you have used your one opportunity to inherit.
If POJOs can be avoided, and you are happy to use Persistents as your base class then that is the best way to use POEM however if you want to POEM enables you to persist a POJO Object graph to a database, which can be useful for reporting, migrating to POEM or as your main persistance mechanism.
HibernatePOEM
Requires a noArg constructor YesYes
Setters and getters must be public NoYes
Persist public fields Not by defaultNo
Use existing id fields YesNo
Fields must have both a setter and a getter Not sureyes
POEM enforces Hibernate best practice, except we do not believe that POEM's Id field should rely upon any existing Id field, so if your POJO has a field called id then the troid column name will be poemId and your id field will be used as a normal field. One assumes that the underlying database will plan queries effectively.
